document.docTitle: Heterologous production of labdane-type diterpenes in the green alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Heterologous production of labdane-type diterpenes in the green alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii

paragraph.docTitle: Heterologous production of labdane-type diterpenes in the green alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii

subSection.paragraph:
Paola Ferrante b , Giovanni Giuliano
b, ∗
, Angelos K. Kanellis
a,
∗∗

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Group of Biotechnology of Pharmaceutical Plants, Laboratory of Pharmacognosy, Department of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki,

paragraph.emphasis: ENEA, Italian National Agency for New Technologies, Energy and Sustainable Economic Development, Casaccia Research Center, 00123, Rome, Italy

subSection.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O

Chlamydomonas reinhardtii P.A.Dangeard
( Chlamydomonadaceae )

Cistus creticus
L. ( Cistaceae )
Microalgae
Heterologous production
Copal-8-ol diphosphate synthase Labdane diterpenes
Ent -manoyl oxide
Ent -13- epi -manoyl oxide Labda-13-ene-8 α ,15-diol Labda-14-ene-8,13-diol (sclareol)
A B S T R A C T

Labdane diterpenes (LDs), and especially sclareol, are important feedstocks for the pharmaceutical and cosmetic industries, and therefore several lines of research have led to their heterologous production in non-photosynthetic microbes and higher plants. The potential of microalgae as bioreactors of natural products has been established for a variety of bioactive metabolites, including terpenes. In this work, a codon optimized sequence encoding a key plant labdane-type diterpene (LD) cyclase, copal-8-ol diphosphate synthase from
Cistus creticus ( CcCLS )
, was introduced into the chloroplast genome of
Chlamydomonas reinhardtii.
Of 49 transplastomic algal lines, 12 produced variable amounts of four LD compounds, namely ent -manoyl oxide, sclareol, labda-13-ene-8 α ,15-diol and ent -13- epi -manoyl oxide. The total LD concentrations measured in the transplastomic lines reached 1.172 ± 0.05 μg/mg cell DW for the highest overall producer, while the highest yield for sclareol was 0.038 ± 0.001 μg/mg cell DW. Thus, transplastomic expression of a key plant labdane diterpene cyclase in the
C. reinhardtii
chloroplast genome enabled the production of important plant-specific LD compounds.

Microalgae constitute a functionally, physiologically and ecologically diverse group endowed with a great wealth of bioactive compounds ( Cardozo et al., 2007 ; Sasso et al., 2012), playing significant roles in the balance and operation of the planet's ecosystems ( Cavalier-Smith, 2007 ; Hopes and Mock, 2015 ). Along with this biochemical diversity, many eukaryotic microalgae offer several advantages for the molecular farming of bioactive compounds, including fast growth rate, ease of cultivation, autotrophy, and capacity to grow in bioreactors ( Gimpel et al., 2015 ; Ruffing, 2011). One of the most widely used organisms is the chlorophyte
Chlamydomonas reinhardtii
( Chlamydomonadaceae ) ( Neupert et al., 2012 ; Rosales-Mendoza et al., 2011; Scaife et al., 2015), a model unicellular microalgal species, extensively characterized at molecular level ( Ghamsari et al., 2011 ; Gomes de Oliveira Dal’ Molin et al., 2011; Maul et al., 2002 ; Merchant et al., 2007 ). Recombinant protein production has been achieved in this species by transformation of either the nucleus, the mitochondrion, or the chloroplast ( Demurtas et al., 2013 ; Gangl et al., 2015 ; Neupert et al., 2012 ; Rosales-Mendoza et al., 2011; Scaife et al., 2015).
Chlamydomonas
is considered a valuable industrial biotechnology platform (Scaife et al., 2015), especially for products from plants, with which it shares many of the essential and specialized biosynthetic pathways, including that leading to the synthesis of terpenoids ( Lange et al., 2000 ; Lohr et al., 2012 ; Schwender et al., 2001).

Terpenoids constitute the largest group of natural products in both microalgae and plants, among which C 20 diterpenes have the most important pharmacological functions ( Cardozo et al., 2007 ; Pattanaik and Lindberg, 2015; Tholl, 2015). A rich source of plant diterpenes is
Cistus creticus
L. ( Cistaceae ), an angiosperm species native to the Greek island of Crete , that carries glands on its leaves secreting a resin consisting mainly of terpenoids, including labdane-type diterpenoids (LDs), which have significant antimicrobial and cytotoxic activities ( Papaefthimiou et al., 2014 ). Due to their cosmetic and pharmacological applications, pathway discovery and genetic engineering of LD biosynthetic pathways has gained much attention. The first plant
* Corresponding author.
** Corresponding author.

E-mail addresses: dimitra.papaefthimiou@gmail.com (D. Papaefthimiou), gianfranco.diretto@enea.it (G. Diretto), olivia.demurtas@enea.it (O. C . Demurtas), paola.mini@enea.it (P. Mini), paola.ferrante@enea.it (P. Ferrante), giovanni.giuliano@enea.it (G. Giuliano), kanellis@pharm.auth.gr (A.K. Kanellis).
1 Present address: Laboratory of Botany, Department of Biological Sciences and Applications, University of Ioannina, Ioannina, Greece .
https://doi.org/ 10.1016/j.phytochem.2019.112082

Received 4 November 2018 ; Received in revised form 30 July 2019 ; Accepted 2 August 2019 enzyme of the LD biosynthetic pathway to be functionally characterized was copal-8-ol diphosphate synthase (CcCLS), isolated from the glandular trichomes of
C. creticus ( Falara et al., 2010 )
. Copal-8-ol diphosphate synthase (CLS) is a type II diterpene synthase (diTPS) that catalyzes the biosynthesis of copal-8-ol diphosphate from geranylgeranyl diphosphate (GGDP). The product of the reaction is a key intermediate metabolite that can be further cyclized to ent -manoyl-oxide, ent -13- epi -manoyl-oxide, labda-13-ene-8 α ,15-diol and labda-14-ene-8,13-diol (sclareol) ( Falara et al., 2010 ; Papaefthimiou et al., 2014 ; Sallaud et al., 2012; Schalk et al., 2012) ( Fig. 1 ). Homologs of the enzyme from
Nicotiana tabacum
L. ( Solanaceae ) (Sallaud et al., 2012) and from
Salvia sclarea
L. ( Lamiaceae ) ( Caniard et al., 2012 ; Schalk et al., 2012) have been functionally characterized and shown to be involved in the synthesis of ( Z )-labda-12,14-dien-8-ol ( Z -abienol) and sclareol, respectively. Sclareol, a LD isolated originally from clary sage (
Salvia sclarea
), is an essential feedstock for the fine chemicals industry, where it is used for the production of a semisynthetic substitute of ambergris, a highly prized fragrance produced by the intestinal tract of the sperm whale ( Coste-Manière et al., 1988 ). In
S. sclarea ,
the production of sclareol involves the action of two enzymes, a class II enzyme (CLS) and a class I sclareol synthase ( Caniard et al., 2012 ; Schalk et al., 2012), a case that apparently differs from that of
C. creticus ,
where extensive RNA-seq of isolated trichomes and fruit was unable to detect any class I labdane-type diterpene synthase genes, while it detected additional class II enzymes (unpublished data) ( Fig. 1 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 1. Proposed pathway of labdane-type diterpenes predominant in Cistus creticus L. resin. A protonation-initiated cyclization, catalyzed by CcCLS, converts GGDP to the stable bicyclic intermediate copal-8-ol diphosphate. The formation of labda-13-ene-8α,15-diol, ent-manoyl oxide, ent-13-epi manoyl oxide and sclareol are probably due to the activity of non-specific terpenoid phosphatases. Abbreviations: CcCLS, Cistus creticus copal-8-ol diphosphate synthase.

subSection.paragraph:
Microalgae have been used for the heterologous production of isoprenoid compounds such as sterols, terpenoids and carotenoids ( Arendt et al., 2016 ; Fukusaki et al., 2003 ; Gimpel et al., 2015 ; Kempinski et al., 2015 ; Lange and Ahkami, 2013 ; Vickers et al., 2014). Plants produce terpenoid compounds from isopentenyl diphosphate (IPP) and dimethylallyl pyrophosphate (DMAPP), synthesized both via the cytoplasmic mevalonate (MVA) pathway, and via the plastid methyl-D-erythritol 4-phosphate/1-deoxy-D-xylulose 5-phosphate (MEP/DXP) pathway (Tholl, 2015), while Chlorophyta, including
C. reinhardtii
, employ exclusively the MEP/DXP pathway for the production of these metabolites ( Lange et al., 2000 ; Lohr et al., 2012 ; Schwender et al., 2001). Heterologous production in
C. reinhardtii
was achieved for the monoterpene limonene (Syrenne, 2016), and the sesquiterpenes patchulol ( Lauersen et al., 2016 ) and α -bisabolene (Wichmann et al., 2018). More recently, the genes of a cytochrome P450 enzyme ( Gangl et al., 2015 ) and the bifunctional cis -abienol synthase ( AbCAS ) (Zedler et al., 2015), were expressed in
C. reinhardtii
plastids. Another LD, the forskolin diterpenoid precursor 13R(+) manoyl oxide was produced in
Chlamydomonas
by heterologous expression of a plant diterpenoid synthase ( Lauersen et al., 2018 ).

The key role played by CLS in the biosynthesis of several LD compounds makes it an attractive target for metabolic engineering. In this work, chloroplast transformation of
C. reinhardtii
was performed with a codon optimized version of the
C. creticus
copal-8-ol diphosphate synthase (CO-CcCLS). The final products of this manipulation were entmanoyl oxide, sclareol, labda-13-ene-8 α ,15-diol and ent -13- epi -manoyl oxide.

paragraph.emphasis:
2.1. Transformation of the Chlamydomonas chloroplast with a codonoptimized
CcCLS gene (CO-CcCLS)

subSubSection.paragraph:
The CDS of the
C. creticus CcCLS
gene was codon-optimized for improved expression in the
C. reinhardtii
chloroplast ( CO-CcCLS ) (Supplementary Fig. 1 ). CO-CcCLS was cloned without the transit peptide as an N-terminal fusion with the FLAG–tag in the pCG2-FLAG chloroplast expression vector, under the control of the PSBD promoter/ 5′UTR and PSBA terminator/3′UTR ( Fig. 2A ). The obtained construct (pCG2-FLAG- CO-CcCLS ) was introduced in the chloroplast of the cell wall-less cw15 strain using glass beads transformation (Demurtas et al.,

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. Chloroplast transformation of C. reinhardtii with recombinant CO-CcCLS gene, and verification of transgene integration and homoplasmy. A. Schematic map of pCG2-FLAG-CO-CcCLS vector used for chloroplast transformation. The length of each genetic element is indicated in each box. atpA prom.: Promoter of the α- subunit of the chloroplast ATP synthase; aadA: CDS of spectinomycin resistance gene; rbcL Ter.: ribulose bisphosphate carboxylase large chain Terminator; psbA Ter.: Photosystem II protein D1 Terminator; CO-CcCLS: Codon adapted CLS gene; FLAG: Flag Tag; psbD prom.: Photosystem II protein D2 promoter. B. Integration scheme of pCG2-FLAG-CO-CcCLS plasmid in the chloroplast genome. Primers Chla1-for/Chla1-rev (amplicon 1: length 1358 bp) and Chla2-for/Chla2-rev (amplicon2: length 2519 bp) were used to test correct integration in the chloroplast genome while primers Chla3-for/Chla3-rev were used to check homoplasmy (amplicon 3: length 954 bp). The absence of amplicon 3 indicates that the transformants are homoplasmic for the presence of transgene. C. PCR results of seventeen representative transformants. Transformants indicated in red have correct plasmid integration and are homoplasmic. M: 1 kb DNA ladder (NEB, catalog number N3232S).

subSubSection.paragraph: 2013). Chloroplast transformants were selected on TAP agar plates supplemented with 100 μg/ml spectinomycin and subcultured for 10 rounds in the same medium to eliminate all wild-type copies of the chloroplast genome, a condition known as homoplasmy. Correct integration in the chloroplast genome and homoplasmy were verified by PCR with appropriate primers ( Fig. 2 ) ( Demurtas et al., 2013 ). In total, 79 transformants were tested by PCR and 49 of them showed correct integration and homoplasmy. Fig. 2C shows the PCR results of seventeen representative transformants, where only twelve had correct integration and homoplasmy.

heading.emphasis: 2.2. Screening of homoplasmic lines by GC-MS analysis

subSection.paragraph:
To verify the functionality of CO-CcCLS introduced into the
C. reinhardtii
chloroplast, an initial screening of the 49 homoplasmic lines grown in photomixotrophic conditions was performed for detecting semi-volatile labdane diterpene (LD) metabolites by GC-MS. Retention time and mass spectra were tested against an authentic standard of manoyl oxide C 13 epimers mixture, from which product 1a was identified as ent -manoyl oxide and 1b was ent -13- epi -manoyl oxide (Supplementary Fig. 2 ). In 12 out of 49 lines (CLS1, CLS2, CLS4, CLS5, CLS6, CLS8, CLS9, CLS10, CLS11, CLS13, CLS14 and CLS38), hereinafter referred to as CLS-OX lines, the two products were clearly detectable.

For better detection and quantification, a more sensitive GC-MS analytical method was set up in Selected Ion Monitoring (SIM) mode and used to screen the CLS-OX lines, enabling the identification of all four LD compounds, namely ent -manoyl-oxide, ent -13- epi -manoyl-oxide, labda-13-ene-8 α ,15-diol and labda-14-ene-8,13-diol (sclareol).

Fig. 3 shows, as an example, the GC-MS chromatograms of the
Chlamydomonas
wild type cw15 strain (CrWT), of transformant CLS9 and of
C. creticus
resin. Concentrations of produced LDs were expressed in μg/ mg microalgae cells dry weight (Fig. 4, Supplementary Table 1), using a sclareol authentic standard calibration curve (Supplementary Fig. 3 ). In all CLS-OX lines, the highest yield (0.115–1.082 μg/mg DW) was obtained for ent -manoyl oxide, followed by sclareol (0.024–0.038 μg/mg DW), labda-13-ene-8 α ,15-diol (0.022–0.036 μg/mg DW) and e nt -13- epi - manoyl oxide (0.021–0.026 μg/mg DW) (Fig. 4, Supplementary Table 1). Line CLS38 was the highest producer of total LDs (1.172 ± 0.05 μg/mg DW) while line CLS9 was the highest sclareol producer (0.038 ± 0.001 μg/mg DW) (Fig. 4, Supplementary Table 1).

heading.emphasis: 2.3. CO-CcCLS protein accumulation in transplastomic transformants

subSection.paragraph: CO-CcCLS protein accumulation in the 12 transplastomic transformants (CLS-OX lines) producing LDs was evaluated by immunoblotting, using total protein extracts and an anti-FLAG monoclonal antibody ( Fig. 5 ). The results clearly illustrate the presence of a specific band with the expected molecular weight (86.9 KDa) only in the pCG2- FLAGCO-CcCLS transformants. Several non-specific bands were present in all transformants, including the ones obtained using the pCG2- FLAG empty vector. The highest protein accumulation was observed in the CLS8 transformant (indicated in red in Fig. 5 ).

heading.emphasis: 2.4. LD accumulation under di ff erent growth conditions

subSection.paragraph:
Recombinant yeast cells overexpressing CO-CcCLS show increased production of sclareol when cultured in low pH ( Ignea et al., 2015a , 2015b ). To evaluate the relevance of such manipulation in
C. reinhardii , CLS-OX
line CLS9 was chosen, since it is the highest producer for sclareol and labda-13-ene-8 α , 15 diol. Line CLS9 was cultivated in photomixotrophic conditions at pH 7.0 (the usual pH of the TAP medium) and pH 6.0, the lowest pH compatible with cell growth. Lowering of the pH to 6.0 caused only minor changes in the overall LD composition (Supplementary Fig. 4 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 3. GC-TQMS chromatograms in Selected Ion Monitoring (SIM) mode. Production of labdane diterpenes (ent-manoyl oxide, ent-13-epi manoyl oxide, sclareol and labda-13-ene-8α,15-diol) in C. reinhardtii strain cw15, wild-type (CrWT) and expressing the CLS gene from C. creticus (CLS9). A SIM chromatogram from C. creticus resin has been included as comparison (CcResin). SIM chromatograms were acquired by monitoring m/z 257, 272, 275, 290 and 308.

Fig. 4. Accumulation of labdane diterpenes in C. reinhardtii strain cw15 overexpressing the CLS gene from C. creticus . Concentrations of the 4 LD’ s detected in 12 independent CLS-OX transformants, measured by GC-MS. Data are expressed as μg/mg normalized on the dry cell weight (DW). Error bars show standard deviations between 3 biological replicates. SIM signal intensity of the GC-MS chromatograms were acquired monitoring m/z 257, 272, 275, 290 and 308. Absolute values were obtained using a sclareol authentic standard calibration curve (Supplementary Figure 3).

Fig. 5. Expression of the CLS protein in C. reinhardtii transformants. A. Immunoblotting performed with an anti-FLAG monoclonal antibody on total proteins (10 µg) extracted from C. reinhardtii transformants overexpressing the FLAG-CO-CcCLS gene. B. Ponceau staining showing protein loading. The number on each well indicates the corresponding CLS-OX transformant. M: Molecular weight marker (Dual color Pre-stained Bio-rad, catalog number 1610374). (-): Chlamydomonas cells transformed with the pCG2-FLAG empty vector.

subSection.paragraph:
In the present work, expression of a codon-optimized
C. creticus CLS
gene in
C. reinhardtii
chloroplasts led to the biosynthesis of four LDs with high pharmaceutical value, specifically ent -manoyl oxide, sclareol, labda-13-ene-8 α ,15-diol and ent -13- epi -manoyl oxide. Of 49 homoplasmic transformants analyzed by GC-MS, 12 were identified as high LD producers, albeit the CLS expression levels were unrelated to the final LD product concentrations. On average, the highest relative abundance was shown by ent -manoyl oxide (83.6%), followed by sclareol (6.1%), labda-13-ene-8 α ,15-diol (5.5%) and ent -13- epi -manoyl oxide (4.8%) (Supplementary Table 1). This composition differs largely from that of the
C. creticus
resin, containing ent -13- epi -manoyl oxide as the major compound, followed by ent -manoyl oxide and trace amounts of labda-13-ene-8 α ,15-diol and sclareol ( Anastasaki et al., 1999 ; Demetzos et al., 2002 ; Papaefthimiou et al., 2014 ).

In vitro LD biosynthesis using CcCLS and other plant copal-8-ol diphosphate synthases, followed by dephosphorylation of the product, resulted in the synthesis of labda-13-ene-8 α ,15-diol as the major product, with trace amounts of ent -manoyl oxide C 13 epimers and sclareol ( Caniard et al., 2012 ; Falara et al., 2010 ; Pateraki et al., 2014; Sallaud et al., 2012; Zerbe et al., 2012). Expression of CcCLS in a yeast vector system using a modular approach led to the accumulation, in the culture medium, of labda-13-ene-8 α ,15-diol in cells grown at neutral pH, and of sclareol in cells grown at pH 3.5–4.5 ( Ignea et al., 2015a , 2015b ). These findings suggest that sclareol is produced through acid hydrolysis in the medium, in the absence of sclareol synthase. In our work, sclareol production was already high at pH 7.0, and was not influenced by the pH of the medium (Supplementary Fig. 4 ). The formation of all four LDs in our transformants is probably due to direct conversion from copal-8-ol diphosphate, the product of CLS enzymatic activity ( Fig. 1 ). It is therefore possible that, in
C. reinhardtii ,
copal-8-ol diphosphate is converted into LDs, including sclareol, through the action of non-specific terpenoid phosphatases. Genetic manipulation of such phosphatases, and/or introduction of genes specifically leading to the production of any of the 4 LDs shown in Fig. 1 , such as CLS coupled with the
S. sclarea
sclareol synthase, may lead to higher levels of sclareol.

Aromatic and medicinal plants are valuable sources of natural products. However, since most of them are not amenable to genetic manipulation, it is difficult to obtain strains producing higher amounts of these compounds. In the present work, we have demonstrated the potential of
C. reinhardtii
to use its biochemical arsenal for producing high levels of bioactive LDs in the absence of metabolic optimization steps. The availability of genome-scale models for
C. reinhardtii
metabolism ( Chang et al., 2011 ) paves the way for further optimization of the production of these important bioactive compounds.

heading.emphasis: 4.1. Cloning of CO-CcCLS gene in a vector for chloroplast transformation

subSection.paragraph:
The CDS region for the CLS gene, corresponding to the
C. creticus
( Cistaceae ) transcript (accession number HM537017), was codon optimized ( CO-CcCLS ) according to
Chlamydomonas chloroplast
codon usage, using the Optimizer application (http://genomes.urv.es/ OPTIMIZER) as described in Demurtas et al. (2013) . The CO-CcCLS sequence without the chloroplast transit peptide (Supplementary

Fig. 1), flanked at 5′ by Nd eI and Ag eI and at 3′ by Eco RI restriction sites, was commercially synthesized by Genscript Co. (USA) and cloned at the Ag eI/ Eco RI target sites of the pCG2-FLAG vector, having a FLAG tag located at the 5’ of the gene (Fig. 2A). The pCG2-FLAG vector was obtained through digestion of vector pCG1 ( Demurtas et al., 2013 ) with enzymes EcoRI / NdeI , filling in with DNA Polymerase I, Large (Klenow) Fragment (NEB M0210S) and through cloning of the expression cassette containing regulatory regions between XmaI and NotI sites ( Demurtas et al., 2013 ). The obtained construct pCG2-FLAG- CO-CcCLS was verified by sequencing and used to transform the
C. reinhardtii
strain cw15 (Chlamydomonadaceae) chloroplast as described below.

paragraph.emphasis: 4.2. Chlamydomonas strains , transformation and growth conditions

subSection.paragraph:
The cell wall-less
C. reinhardtii
strain cw15 was grown on a rotary shaker photomixotrophically in Tris acetate phosphate (TAP), pH 7.0 medium at 25 ̊C at a photoperiod of 16 h light (120 μE m −2 s −1 ) and 8 h dark. For transformation, cells were grown to mid-log phase (concentration of 5 × 10 6 cells/ml, counted using a TC10 automated cell counter (Bio-Rad, California , USA ), and chloroplast transformation was performed as previously described ( Demurtas et al., 2013 ).
C. reinhardtii
cells transformed with the empty vector pCG2-FLAG were used as negative controls in all subsequent analyses. Transformants were propagated for 10 rounds in selective TAP agar medium, pH 7.0, supplemented with 100 μg/ml spectinomycin to obtain homoplasmic lines.

To verify correct integration in the chloroplast genome and successful homoplasmy, total DNA was extracted from all transformants with a standard phenol/chloroform extraction protocol (Sambrook and Russell, 2006). Correct integration of plasmid DNA was checked by PCR amplification ( Demurtas et al., 2013 ) with the following primers: Chla1-for 5′-ACAACTAAAATTGTTAGTTTCTT-3′ and Chla1-rev 5′-TGC CTCTAATAAAGTCATCG-3′, Chla2-for 5′-TCAAGCACTCATGTGAT TTT-3′ and Chla2-rev 5′-AAAACGAATCCATTACGATTA-3’. Homoplasmy was checked with primers Chla3-for 5′-CACGTTTAACGGCGTC CTTTA-3′ and Chla3-rev 5′-ACTTATCTGATTCAAAAGTA-3′ as showed in Fig. 2B . The expected amplicon sizes were 1.358 bp for Chla1, 2.519 bp for Chla2, and 954 bp for Chla3 amplicons. The presence of amplicons Chla1 and Chla2 indicates correct plasmid integration in the chloroplast genome. The absence of amplicon Chla3 indicates that the transformants are homoplasmic for the presence of the transgene ( Fig. 2B and C ).

heading.emphasis: 4.3. Screening of homoplasmic lines by GC-MS analysis

subSection.paragraph:
Screening of
C. reinhardtii
transformants for LD production was performed on 49 homoplasmic lines, grown to a density of 2 × 10 6 cells/ml in 200 ml of liquid TAP medium at pH 7.0, supplemented with 20 μg/ml spectinomycin. Cells were harvested by centrifugation at 3000 g at 4 ̊ C for 10 min and pellets were resuspended in 6 ml of hexane. Extraction was performed by vortexing for 1 min and sonicating in an ultrasonic bath for 2 × 30 min. Samples were then centrifuged at 8000 g for 20 min at room temperature (RT) and the supernatant was collected and concentrated by a Speedvac concentrator to a final volume of 100 μl. One μl of extract was subjected to gas chromatography-mass spectrometry analysis (GC-MS) as previously described ( Falara et al., 2010 ). GC-MS analysis was performed in scan mode with the apolar MEGA-5 MS column (MEGA, Legnano (MI) Italy ) using a Shimadzu QP-2010 system (SHIMADZU, Kyoto , Japan ) with electronic ionization set at 70 eV. A mixture of ent -manoyl oxide and ent -13- epi -manoyl oxide was used as standard ( Falara et al., 2010 ). Extracts of
C. reinhardtii
transformed with the empty vector pCG2- FLAG were used as a negative control. To calculate the peak retention index (RI), a mixture of C 9 – C 25 alkanes was used (van Den Dool and Dec. Kratz, 1963). To study the influence of pH on LDs production, pCG2 (containing the empty vector) and CLS9 transformants were grown in 50 ml TAP , pH 7.0, with 20 μg/ml spectinomycin (Sueoka, 1960) for 72 h at 25 ̊ C in continuous light (120 μE m −2 s −1 ), and then diluted 1: 20 in 20 ml of TAP medium at pH 6.0 and pH 7.0 (two biological replications for each transformant). After 96 h, cells were collected by centrifugation at 3000 g at 4 ̊ C for 10 min and the pellets were processed as described in section 4.5.

To verify correct expression of the CO-CcCLS protein in
Chlamydomonas
, protein blot analysis was performed on the 12 transformants accumulating the highest LD levels. The transformants were grown in the same conditions described above at pH 7.0. Total protein was extracted from 6 × 10 6 cells by directly re-suspending the cell pellets in 50 μl of SDS-loading buffer (10% glycerol, 50 mM Tris-HCl pH 6.8, 0.1% bromophenol blue, 2% SDS, 2.5% 2-mercaptoethanol). Samples were then boiled for 10 min, centrifuged at 18,000 g for 30 min at RT and 5 μl of the supernatant were subjected to 10% SDS-PAGE in a Mini Protean apparatus (Bio-Rad, California , USA ). Proteins were subsequently transferred onto a PVDF membrane (GE Healthcare, USA ) using the Trans-Blot Turbo system (Bio-Rad, California , USA ). After blocking overnight at 4 ̊ C with 5% non-fat dry milk in PBS (20 mM Na 2 HPO 4 , 2 mM NaH 2 PO 4 150 mM NaCl; pH 7.2), membranes were incubated for 2 h at RT with a 1:2000 dilution of a monoclonal antiFLAG antibody M2-Peroxidase (Sigma-Aldrich, Germany ). The bound antibody was revealed using the ECL Plus system “Enhanced ChemiLuminescence” (GE Healthcare, USA ) and detected by luminometry with a Chemidoc ImageLab system with ImageLab 4.0 software (Bio-Rad, California , USA ).

The 12 transformants accumulating the highest LD levels (CLS-OX) were further characterized by using a GC coupled to a triple quadrupole MS (GC-TQMS TSQ8000 (ThermoFisher Scientific, MA, USA ), operating in electron ionization. Briefly, these transformants were grown in 25 ml TAP , pH 7.0, with 20 μg/ml spectinomycin, subsequently pelleted at 3000 g for 10 min at 4 ̊ C and re-suspended by vortexing in 700 μl 10 mM Tris-HCl, 1 mM EDTA (TE), pH 8.0. Cells were then lysed by sonication on ice at 10 Hz output (10 s each) for 3 times and 700 μl of hexane was added. Next, samples were centrifuged at 8000 g for 20 min at 4 ̊ C , the supernatant collected, dried in a concentrator and resuspended in 20 μl of hexane. One μl was injected using a TriPlus RSH autosampler (Thermofisher Scientific, MA, USA ), and semi-volatile metabolites, including labdane diterpenes, were separated using a Thermo TG-SQC column ( 15m × 0.25 mm x 0.25 μm), with helium as carrier gas at a constant flow of 1.2 mL/min. Oven temperature conditions were: 40 ̊ C for 1 min, 20 ̊ C /min ramp until 120 ̊ C and 10 ̊ C / min until 250 ̊ C , which was held for 5 min. Mass spectra (MS) were recorded in scan mode in the 45–450 m /z range, and in Selected Ion Monitoring mode using typical transitions for the 4 labdane diterpenes (m/z 257, 272, 275, 290 and 308). MS transfer line temperature and Ion Source temperature were set at 240 ̊ C and 250 ̊ C , respectively. Chromatograms and spectra were recorded and analyzed using the Excalibur software (Thermofisher Scientific, MA, USA ). All solvents used were LC-MS grade (Merck Millipore, MA, USA ). Labdane diterpenes were unequivocally identified by comparing mass spectra and retention times with authentic standards ( Falara et al., 2010 ) and by interrogation of the NIST 17 mass spectral library. For quantifying the concentrations of the 4 LDs in each transplastomic line, a calibration curve was constructed with a commercial sclareol standard (Sigma-Aldrich, Germany , Cat. No. 49944), using 3 replicates per point (Supplementary Fig. 2 ). Sclareol calibration curve data were interpolated with LD signal intensities of each microalgal line, and metabolite quantification was performed using peak areas normalized by the microalgal dry weight.
The authors declare no conflict of interest.

The work was supported by a post-doctoral fellowship by the Greek General Secretariat for Research & Technology “Education and Lifelong Learning” (NSRF 2007–2013/LS9 (189) and a travel grant (ECOSTSTSM-FA1006-180214-037883) to D. Papaefthimiou.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2019.112082.
